(a) Find the length of the curve ⃗r(t) from ⃗r(0) = (0, 1, 0) to ⃗r(π) = (π, −1, π2/2). (b) Find the curvature of the curve at time t = π. Solution. We compute v = (cos t − cos t + t sin t, − sin t + sin t + t cos t, t) = (t sin t, t cos t, t). The speed is |v| = √t2 sin 2 t + t2 cos2 t + t2 = √ 2t. Therefore the arclength is ∫ π 0 |v|dt = ∫ π 0 √ 2tdt = √ 2         π 0 t 2 2 = π2 √ 2 . For the curvature, we use κ = |v × a|/|v| 3. The acceleration is a = (sin t + t cos t, cos t − t sin t, 1). (10 pts) Consider the vector ﬁeld ⃗F given by ⃗F = x − 2y x2 + y2 ˆi + 2x + y x2 + y2 ˆj + (z2 + z) ˆk. (a) Determine the domain of ⃗F. (b) Compute ∇ × ⃗F. (c) Evaluate the line integral ∫ C ⃗F · dr where C is the circle of radius 1 in the plane z = 5, centered at (0, 0, 5) and traversed clockwise if viewed from the positive z-axis. (d) Is ⃗F conservative? Page 1 Math 317 Old Final Exam Solution. The domain is R 3\{x = y = 0}. We compute A = ∂ ∂x 2x + y x2 + y2 = 2(x2 + y2) −1 − (2x + y)(x2 + y2) −2(2x) = 2x2 + 2y2 − 4x2 − 2xy (x2 + y2)2 . and B = ∂ ∂y x − 2y x2 + y2 = −2(x2 + y2) −1 − (x − 2y)(x2 + y2) −2(2y) = −2x2 − 2y2 − 2xy + 4y2 (x2 + y2)2 . From here, ∇ × F =           i j k ∂x ∂y ∂z x−2y x2+y2 2x+y x2+y2 z2 + z           = (0, 0, A − B) = (0, 0, 0). Next, parametrize C by r = (cos t, − sin t, 5), 0 ≤ t ≤ 2π. Then F(r(t)) = (cos t + 2 sin t, 2 cos t − sin t, 30), and the line integral is ∫ 2π 0 (cos t + 2 sin t, 2 cos t − sin t, 30) · (− sin t, − cos t, 0)dt which becomes ∫ 2π 0 −(2 sin 2 t + 2 cos 2 t)dt = −(2)(2π) = −4π. It follows that F is not conservative, since the main theorem on conservative vector ﬁelds states that conservative vector ﬁelds satisfy ∫ C F · dr = 0 for all closed curves C. 3. (10 pts) Let C be the curve of intersection of the surfaces z = x2 +y2 and z = 2y+2x+5 oriented counterclockwise when viewed from above. Compute the line integral ∫ C ⃗F · dr for the vector ﬁeld ⃗F = (−y + x2, x + y2, z2). Solution. We will use Stokes’ theorem, so we compute ∇ × F = (0, 0, 2). Page 5 Math 317 Old Final Exam The curve bounds the surface S given by z = f (x, y) = 2x + 2y + 5 and x2 + y2 ≤ z. By Stokes’ theorem ∫ C F · dr = ∫ ∫ S(∇ × F) · ndS = The normal is ndS = (−fx, −fy, 1)dxdy which becomes ndS = (−2 − 2, 1)dxdy Taking the dot product ∫ ∫ S(∇ × F) · ndS = ∫ ∫ S 2dxdy. The surface S is given by x2 + y2 ≤ 2x + 2y + 5 which after completing the square becomes (x − 1) 2 + (y − 1)2 ≤ 7 The area of this circle is 7π, so the ﬁnal answer is (2)(7π) = 14π. 7. (10 pts) Let a, b ∈ R be constants, and consider the vector ﬁeld ⃗F = (xz + y2, axeyz + byz, 2 − xeyz2). (a) Find the constants a, b such that ⃗F = ∇ × ⃗A for some vector ﬁeld ⃗A. (b) Let a, b be as in part (a) so that ⃗F admits a vector potential. Evaluate the ﬂux integral ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆn dS where the surface S is the hemisphere given by the equations x2 + y2 + z2 = 2, z ≥ 0 with upward normal. Solution. Since ⃗F is C 1 on R 3, we have that ⃗F admits a vector potential if and only if ∇ · F = 0. We compute ∇ · F = z + axe yz + bz − 2xeyz Setting this zero, we obtain a = 2 and b = −1. For (b), we use the technique of switch the surface. This can either be understood using Stokes’ theorem or the divergence theorem. Let’s use the Stokes’ theorem version, which says that if F admits a vector potential then it has the “surface independence property”. Page 6 Math 317 Old Final Exam Let S1 be the ﬂat disc at the bottom of the hemisphere: z = 0 and x2 + y2 ≤ 2. Then ndS = (0, 0, 1)dxdy. The integral is ∫ ∫ S F · ˆndS = ∫ ∫ x2+y2≤2(∗, ∗, 2 − 0) · (0, 0, 1)dxdy = 2 ∫ ∫ x2+y2≤2 dxdy. The ﬂux is then 4π. 8. (10 pts) Recall the notation ρ = ρ(x, y, z) = √ x2 + y2 + z2. (a) Compute the constants a, b such that ∇ 2ρ 1/2 = aρ−b. (b) Compute lim ε→0 ∫ ∫ ∂Bε(0)(∇2ρ1/2) dS or show that the limit does not exist.
